[Morning Docket](https://abovethelaw.com/morning-docket/)
# Morning Docket: 05.23.18
## * A trio of big name partners -- including the group co-chairs -- are leaving the products liability group at Quinn Emanuel for Dechert. So far there's no [email](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/02/john-quinn-is-not-happy-about-selendy-gay-and-he-sent-the-angry-reply-all-to-prove-it/) from John Quinn blasting the move. [[Law.com](https://www.law.com/2018/05/22/queen-of-toxic-torts-leaves-quinn-emanuel-for-dechert-with-two-partners/)] * Former Michael Cohen business partner, Evgeny "Gene" Freidman, has taken a plea deal and will cooperate with the government. The [pressure on Cohen](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/michael-cohen-put-up-his-home-as-collateral-now-what-are-the-chances-hell-flip-on-trump/) just keeps on mounting. [[New York Times](https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/22/nyregion/michael-cohen-trump-taxi-cooperation.html)] * Michigan State named a new General Counsel, Robert Young. That [poor bastard](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/the-absolute-worst-in-house-job-right-now/). [[Corporate Counsel](https://www.law.com/2018/05/22/from-frying-pan-to-fire-msu-names-robert-young-as-new-general-counsel/)] * A couple trying to get their 30-year-old son to move out of their house resort to court proceedings. It... does not work out well for the freeloading son. [[Washington Post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-nation/wp/2018/05/22/a-30-year-old-demanded-six-month-notice-for-eviction-from-his-parents-house-a-judge-called-that-outrageous/?utm_term=.bdd695d447b3)] * You're not wrong to be worried about the merger between AT&T and Time Warner. Things could really go pear-shaped for consumers. [[Slate](https://slate.com/technology/2018/05/at-and-t-and-time-warner-trial-the-case-for-fearing-this-merger.html)]
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onMay 23, 2018 at 8:45 AMMay 23, 2018 at 7:56 AM
4

### [ How Will Walgreens’ Expansion Into Specialty Pharmacy Affect The Industry? ](https://medcitynews.com/2024/04/walgreens-specialty-pharmacy-drugs/)
Walgreens announced that it is expanding its specialty pharmacy offerings. Experts think that this move could yield several strategic benefits, given the higher profit margins associated with specialty medications compared to traditional drugs. They also think Walgreens’ move could lead to greater competition, consolidation, and innovation within the broader pharmacy industry.
By KATIE ADAMS - MEDCITY NEWS

# Bonus Season Has Started, But Where Are The Bonuses? Come On, Cravath!
## Stop keeping everyone waiting.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onNovember 13, 2020 at 10:51 AM
3
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/11/bonus-season-has-started-but-where-are-the-bonuses-come-on-cravath/&text=Bonus%20Season%20Has%20Started,%20But%20Where%20Are%20The%20Bonuses?%20Come%20On,%20Cravath!)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/11/bonus-season-has-started-but-where-are-the-bonuses-come-on-cravath/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/11/bonus-season-has-started-but-where-are-the-bonuses-come-on-cravath/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

Baker McKenzie decided to kick off the 2020 bonus season bright and early on Wednesday morning, announcing the [$15K to $100K scale](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/11/breaking-biglaw-bonus-season-comes-early-and-no-its-not-cravath/) that we’ve seen for years now (while promising to match any increases in the market, should they occur). Thus far, the firm’s announcement has been more or less ignored.

Before you start wondering what the other firms could possibly be waiting for before making their matches, you should know that we’ve seen this before.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Last year, [Milbank made the first move](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/11/breaking-biglaw-bonuses-are-here/) when it came to announcing year-end bonuses, and for five days, partners on Biglaw executive committees sat twiddling their thumbs until [Cravath came forward](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/11/cravath-announces-bonuses-now-the-2019-bonus-season-can-really-begin/) to announce that it was matching the Milbank bonus scale. Only then did matches occur — and at a rapid pace, at that.

Cravath’s seal of approval may be what’s needed here, but let’s face it: we’re dealing with a pandemic and there are already different tiers of compensation across Biglaw.

“This year we see much more of a fragmented system with different firms doing different things,” said Nathan Peart, managing director of Major, Lindsey & Africa’s associate practice group, in an interview with [Am Law](https://www.law.com/2020/11/12/baker-mckenzie-bonuses-met-with-crickets-but-likely-not-for-long/). If you recall, while some firms adopted special fall bonuses on the [Davis Polk scale](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/wow-davis-polk-raises-the-bar-on-bonuses/), others decided either to commit to matching them when year-end bonus time came around or forgo them entirely.

Peart adds that the rest of the market could also be waiting for historical bonus leaders like Cravath or Milbank to make a move before jumping into the fray—a possibility Baker McKenzie seems to have hedged for, by telling its associates that the firm will match any increase to the scale.

“The market does look to the likes of Cravath and Milbank to make that market leap,” Peart said. “I don’t think Baker wants to set a figure and not have any flexibility if the market goes higher. I think it was prudent to do that … It makes sense to say ‘we’re going to match don’t worry about that.’ The psychology is very important internally for the firm.”

# Partners Seem Worried About How Biglaw Behemoth A&O Shearman Will Operate
## There's growing anxiety over who will take the lead at the newly merged firm that's poised to be the third largest in the world.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onFebruary 9, 2024 at 4:16 PMFebruary 9, 2024 at 4:02 PM
4

Ed. note: Welcome to our daily feature, [Quote of the Day](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/quote-of-the-day/).

If I was an A&O partner in the U.S., would I be worried? Yes.

A&O should try and keep the best Shearman partners within the integrated firm. If A&O keeps on taking the lead in the U.S., there is a risk of further Shearman partners leaving, and the merger not being successful.

— A former A&O partner, in anonymous comments given to the [Law.com International](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2024/02/08/there-is-concern-ao-shearman-insiders-on-initial-hurdles-facing-firm-405-136109/) on what could possibly go wrong for A&O Shearman after the [newly merged](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/ao-shearman-merger-approved-poised-to-become-third-largest-firm-in-the-world/) firm’s official launch date in May, from who will lead the firm to how it will operate in the U.S. and across the globe. “In the U.S., there is concern over how the Shearman culture fits in with what we’re doing,” said another lawyer with knowledge of A&O. “It seems impossible that [Shearman partners] won’t be in the driving seat given how many of them there are.”

# Associates Fear Complex Biglaw Bonus Criteria Will Leave Them In The Dust
## How should associates feel about discretionary bonuses?
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onDecember 5, 2016 at 3:11 PM
0
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/associates-fear-complex-biglaw-bonus-criteria-will-leave-them-in-the-dust/&text=Associates%20Fear%20Complex%20Biglaw%20Bonus%20Criteria%20Will%20Leave%20Them%20In%20The%20Dust)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/associates-fear-complex-biglaw-bonus-criteria-will-leave-them-in-the-dust/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/associates-fear-complex-biglaw-bonus-criteria-will-leave-them-in-the-dust/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
There are lots of benefits to lockstep bonuses, or at least bonuses that are triggered when hitting objective metrics like hours. Associates know what is expected of them, there is a greater sense of congeniality amongst lawyers who aren’t backbiting in order to secure themselves more money, and your bonus system doesn’t wind up featured on Above the Law.

On Friday, in an [article about bonus season](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/so-who-is-pissed-about-their-bonuses/), we quoted a current associate at Morgan Lewis who was pissed about a bonus allocation system that left large amounts of money up to discretionary factors (including “firm citizenship” and timekeeping), such that even attorneys that made their hours might not see the full market bonus. But as with all things discretionary, not everyone has the same take. We heard from another tipster who feels certain that the discretionary elements to bonus allocation are not undercover cost cutting measures and that, come bonus time, things will go their way:

Whoever told you that ML “intends to cut bonuses” had an extremely incorrect take away from that presentation.  First off, ML should be applauded for its transparency in letting associates know what to expect and how the process is decided.  I can tell you from personal experience that ML always goes above and beyond in taking care of its associates, and they made clear they intend to continue to do so.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
But that isn’t to say the concerns over the discretionary elements of the bonus payday aren’t justified. Even though Morgan Lewis went into PR triage mode, assuring worried associates the Biglaw Grinch would not be taking away their bonuses, they also didn’t back down from the discretionary factors:

Just a quick update here: we got a panicked voicemail Friday afternoon after the ATL Morgan Lewis [bonus story](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/so-who-is-pissed-about-their-bonuses/) was published. 

The head of “talent management” had been getting calls/emails from associates and she wanted to assure us that the allegations in the ATL story were patently false and that Morgan Lewis pays competitive bonuses, it’s just that bonuses are only paid to associates that satisfy 5 categories of evaluation from firm management (making your hours is just one of the 5, you must also pass muster for quality of work, “firm citizenship”, time keeping etc.).  But not to worry, if you make your hours but miss the mark in one of those other categories, the firm is still generous enough to give you a bonus, they’re just going to reduce it by 25-75% of the market rate. 

So, put another way, “Morgan Lewis has made clear that they intend to cut bonuses for associates that made their hours (2000) by anywhere from 25 to 75% based on subjective factors in the discretion of firm/practice group management”, or exactly what you published on Friday.

So that’s what the associates on the ground are saying. Yes, opinion varies, probably depending on how confident they feel about the discretionary factors in their bonus. Perhaps when payday comes folks will see that their worries were unfounded, but until then the speculation will run wild.

Please help us help you when it comes to bonus news at other firms. As soon as your firm’s bonus memo comes out, please [email it to us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Bonus) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Bonus”) or text us (646-820-8477). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

From Pilot and Above The Law  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)

# Morning Docket: 12.07.16
## * "Voters deserve to know that personal priorities will never take precedence over the national interest." Thanks to President-elect Donald Trump's unwillingness to release his tax returns, a New York lawmaker has introduced the Tax Returns Uniformly Made Public (TRUMP) Act, which would require presidential and vice presidential candidates to disclose their income tax returns going back five years to appear on the ballot in New York. [[Big Law Business](https://bol.bna.com/citing-trump-n-y-legislator-seeks-tax-disclosure-law/)] * In what's being considered a blow to college athletes, the Seventh Circuit has ruled that they are not employees deserving of a minimum wage under the Fair Labor Standards Act. Fortunately, there may be a bright spot of hope in a concurring opinion because it shows that "[t]he nature of the relationship between kids who play FBS football and their schools, leagues and the NCAA ... is a business relationship." [[Huffington Post](http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/college-athletes-compensation_us_5846cab1e4b02f60b024cef6)] * Weil Gotshal snagged a prominent antitrust partner from Simpson Thacher, and it just so happens that he's already great friends with the attorney with whom he'll work alongside of as co-head of the firm's antitrust practice. Congrats to Kevin J. Arquit (and to Steven A. Newborn, who'll be reunited with a friend). [[DealBook / New York Times](http://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/06/business/dealbook/prominent-antitrust-lawyer-to-join-weil-gotshal.html?smid=tw-dealbook&smtyp=cur)] * President-elect Trump may turn to another prosecutor turned Biglaw partner to lead the SEC following the departure of Chairwoman Mary Jo White. It looks like Debra Wong Yang, chair Gibson Dunn's crisis management practice, may become Wall Street's "top cop" under the Trump administration. [[Wall Street Journal](http://www.wsj.com/articles/former-u-s-attorney-debra-wong-yang-being-considered-to-lead-sec-1481051519) (sub. req.)] * If you thought that the American Bar Association had learned its lesson after the closure of Indiana Tech Law, then you thought wrong, because the ABA has granted the UMass Law School full accreditation. Feast your eyes upon these [glorious bar exam passage statistics](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/10/massachusetts-bar-exam-results-reveal-worst-passage-rates-in-almost-25-years/) from the last two July administrations of the test. [[Lowell Sun](http://www.lowellsun.com/breakingnews/ci_30636505/umass-law-school-gets-full-accreditation)]
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onDecember 7, 2016 at 8:57 AMDecember 7, 2016 at 11:09 AM

# Time’s Up For Using Arbitration To Squash Sexual Harassment Claims
## When organizations are using forced-arbitration provisions as a sword instead of a shield to cut civil rights protections, then its peers and employees should call bullsh*t.
By [Renwei Chung](https://abovethelaw.com/author/renweichung/)  
onMarch 30, 2018 at 1:58 PMMarch 30, 2018 at 3:45 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/03/times-up-for-using-arbitration-to-squash-sexual-harassment-claims/&text=Time’s%20Up%20For%20Using%20Arbitration%20To%20Squash%20Sexual%20Harassment%20Claims)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/03/times-up-for-using-arbitration-to-squash-sexual-harassment-claims/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/03/times-up-for-using-arbitration-to-squash-sexual-harassment-claims/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Time’s up.

“Your last chance to negotiate / Send in your seconds / See if they can set the record straight.” — [Lin-Manuel Miranda](https://genius.com/Lin-manuel-miranda-ten-duel-commandments-lyrics)

It’s been quite the week for law firms and labor and employment issues.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
On Monday, our own Staci Zaretsky [reported](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/03/biglaw-firm-tries-to-force-summer-associates-to-arbitrate-sexual-harassment-claims/?rf=1) on how Munger Tolles & Olson (MTO) was “trying to get its incoming summer associates to sign mandatory arbitration agreements — agreements that would have required them to arbitrate all employment-related claims, including sexual harassment claims.”

As Zaretsky noted, the day before, MTO had already issued a public statement via Twitter stating:

Munger Tolles & Olson is committed to the highest standards of conduct. In this case, we were wrong, and we are fixing it. We will no longer require any employees, including summer associates, to sign any mandatory arbitration agreements.

I certainly applaud MTO for recognizing the issue, accepting responsibility, and taking actions to course correct.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)

### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
By Tuesday, Zaretsky reported that the first Biglaw firm, Orrick Herrington & Sutcliffe, would voluntarily — as opposed to feeling the pressure of a social media sh*tstorm — no longer require any of its employees, including associates, to sign mandatory arbitration agreements. “Orrick has decided that it’s time for us to make a change,” the firm said in a statement given to Above the Law.

Is Orrick a harbinger of firms and organizations no longer using arbitration as a sword to cut down sexual harassment claims?

Earlier this year, I had the [opportunity to speak](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/09/the-trump-administration-seeks-to-rip-the-heart-out-of-labor-and-employment-law/) with Michael Rubin, a partner at Altshuler Berzon LLP, and Ceilidh Gao, a National Employment Law Project (NELP) attorney, about a peculiar case that pits the Justice Department directly against the National Relations Labor Board (NLRB).

In this case, SCOTUS is asked to determine: [whether workplace arbitration agreements that ban class actions violate federal labor laws](http://www.scotusblog.com/2017/09/argument-preview-reconciling-class-waivers-national-labor-relations-act/). Between 2012 and 2014, the use of class and collective actions bans in forced arbitration provisions more than doubled, from 16% to 43%. For better or worse, it is becoming crystal clear that organizations are jumping on the arbitration bandwagon and employees are being forced to go along for the ride.

A few years ago, I asked Steven Skulnik, Senior Legal Editor of Arbitration at Thomson Reuters Practical Law: How do you see international and domestic arbitration and mediation evolving over the next decade?

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
He gave quite the [prescient response](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/tips-from-steven-skulnik-on-how-culture-affects-international-and-domestic-arbitration-and-mediation/):

There are certainly headwinds from the courts, regulators and politicians pointing away from arbitration. Arbitration practitioners have a duty to explain the dispute resolution process in the face of misinformation in the media.

While I do think there can be quite a bit of misunderstanding when it comes to the arbitration process, I also believe current business-as-usual arbitration processes are ripe for abuse. When organizations are using forced-arbitration provisions as a sword instead of a shield to cut civil rights protections, then its peers and employees should call bullsh*t.

Any argument for economic efficiency of arbitration procedures or provisions that force non-disclosure of (or otherwise silence) [Title VII claims](https://www.justice.gov/crt/overview-employment-litigation) or ban class actions is greatly outweighed by the [radical tilt in the landscape against employees](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/09/the-trump-administration-seeks-to-rip-the-heart-out-of-labor-and-employment-law/?rf=1).

This week, I attended a fantastic labor and employment presentation titled, “What’s hot in employment and labor law for 2018,” hosted by Norton Rose Fulbright attorneys Mario A. Barrera, James Hughes, and Kelly Klingseisen.

Near the end of their presentation, they went over the history of the [#MeToo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Me_Too_movement) and [Time’s Up](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time's_Up_(movement)) movements and revealed some [very interesting thoughts](https://www.texastribune.org/2018/02/21/uttt-poll-texans-divided-metoo-movement-which-groups-face-most-discrim/) on these grassroots campaigns. There was a general consensus in the room that law firms and other organizations should not be forcing their employees to sign mandatory arbitration agreements that require them to arbitrate Title VII claims, including sexual harassment claims.

This week, Munger Tolles & Olson and Orrick Herrington & Sutcliffe put their money where their mouth is. Will other law firms follow suit?

[Renwei Chung](http://www.muckrack.com/renwei) is the Diversity Columnist at Above the Law. You can contact Renwei by email at [projectrenwei@gmail.com](mailto:projectrenwei@gmail.com?subject=Your%20ATL%20column), follow him on Twitter ([@renweichung](https://twitter.com/RenweiChung)), or connect with him on [LinkedIn](http://www.linkedin.com/in/renweichung/). 

####Topics
[Biglaw](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/biglaw/), [Diversity and Inclusion](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/diversity-and-inclusion/), [Mandatory Arbitration Agreements](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/mandatory-arbitration-agreements/), [Renwei Chung](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/renwei-chung/), [Sexual Harassment](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/sexual-harassment/), [Women's Issues](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/womens-issues/)

# Are More Biglaw Layoffs Looming On The Horizon?
## Survey says most likely. Yikes.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMay 5, 2023 at 2:43 PMMay 5, 2023 at 1:29 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/05/are-more-biglaw-layoffs-looming-on-the-horizon/&text=Are%20More%20Biglaw%20Layoffs%20Looming%20On%20The%20Horizon?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/05/are-more-biglaw-layoffs-looming-on-the-horizon/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/05/are-more-biglaw-layoffs-looming-on-the-horizon/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Ed. note: Welcome to our daily feature, [Quote of the Day](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/quote-of-the-day/).

We would expect to see some more adjustments if the demand picture doesn’t pick up. And unfortunately, we don’t see it picking up.

— Owen Burman, managing director for the Wells Fargo Legal Group, in comments given to the [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/2023/05/02/big-law-surprisingly-strong-so-far-in-2023-but-more-cuts-could-be-on-the-way/) on the likelihood of more layoffs being conducted among Am Law 100 firms in 2023. Wells Fargo is projecting a recession to begin in the second half of the year, which does not bode well for Biglaw. “With the first quarter ending with a mild credit scare and increasing concern about economic growth, we are not surprised by recent press reports of headcount rationalization and postponement of associate starting dates,” the group noted in its most recent report. “While many announcements are among firms that hired most aggressively, other firms may follow suit if the transactional environment fails to improve. In the absence of demand growth, we expect firms to be vigilant on expense management, seeking operational efficiencies to offset required investments for in-person meetings and infrastructure improvements.”

# Flash Poll: Your Firm's Clout In The Cloud
## If you weren’t using cloud-based solutions before the pandemic, you probably are now. How's it going?
By STEPHANIE WILKINS  
onApril 15, 2022 at 12:33 PMApril 15, 2022 at 10:39 AM
34
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/04/flash-poll-your-firms-clout-in-the-cloud/&text=Flash%20Poll:%20Your%20Firm’s%20Clout%20In%20The%20Cloud)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/04/flash-poll-your-firms-clout-in-the-cloud/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/04/flash-poll-your-firms-clout-in-the-cloud/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The concept of “the cloud” is often misunderstood — even though it’s a term that we use all the time.

Confusing matters even more, cloud computing has evolved significantly in the last two years in response to work-from-home and other needs. 

With organizations using cloud-based solutions for legal work more than they ever have before, now is the time to understand exactly what cloud computing is, how it’s helping legal practice, and how to select the right cloud vendor and solutions to meet the individual needs of your practice.

To help lawyers understand the current state of cloud computing in the legal industry, PLI is offering a one-day program, [Cloud Computing 2022](https://www.pli.edu/programs/cloud-computing?t=live), where industry experts will explain the ins and outs of relying on the cloud in modern legal practice.

Among other things, they’ll cover the business realities surrounding cloud computing, what to look for when entering into a cloud computing contract, important privacy and security considerations in cloud computing, and the ethical implications of using cloud-based tools in legal practice.

As always, [visit Practising Law Institute](https://www.pli.edu/) for more.


 

####Topics

# If A Biglaw Firm Falls In The Woods And No One Issues A Press Release About Its Lack Of Diversity...
## This is an industry-wide problem... and it's time to shine the spotlight on the folks keeping quiet about it.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onFebruary 20, 2019 at 10:47 AMFebruary 21, 2019 at 8:27 AM
24
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/02/sullivan-if-a-biglaw-firm-falls-in-the-woods-and-no-one-issues-a-press-release-about-its-lack-of-diversity/&text=If%20A%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Falls%20In%20The%20Woods%20And%20No%20One%20Issues%20A%20Press%20Release%20About%20Its%20Lack%20Of%20Diversity…)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/02/sullivan-if-a-biglaw-firm-falls-in-the-woods-and-no-one-issues-a-press-release-about-its-lack-of-diversity/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/02/sullivan-if-a-biglaw-firm-falls-in-the-woods-and-no-one-issues-a-press-release-about-its-lack-of-diversity/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Outlets like Above the Law don’t report on every Biglaw firm’s new partnership class. Usually, it’s a relatively mundane collection of rising stars that haven’t really made a name for themselves outside the four walls of their well-appointed offices. Beyond allowing everyone to keep tabs on their least favorite gunners, new partnership announcements rarely move the needle. Unfortunately, when it comes to partnership promotions, no news is usually good news.

And that’s exactly why firms with something to hide can sometimes slip one past the media by keeping their mouths shut. Like one firm downtown that hasn’t made any announcement of its new partners even though the firm historically puts out a press release like clockwork at the top of the new year. Last year’s installment — [now conspicuously absent from the Internet](https://www.sullcrom.com/introducing-sullivan-cromwell-eight-newest-partners-2018) — began “S&C has elected eight partners to the partnership effective January 1, 2018.”

We received a tip about S&C’s lack of public announcement way back on January 2. At the time, we hoped it was premature. A month and a half later, it’s clear that it wasn’t.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
I don’t know if Sullivan & Cromwell elected a markedly non-diverse class of new partners. The fact of the matter is no one knows because the firm didn’t trumpet its new class as it has in years past. Even though we could likely reverse engineer this, that’s also not the point — the firm decided against drawing attention to its new partner class for the first time in a long time and given the negative press — some of it starting here — that Paul Weiss received over its partnership class, one has to wonder if the strategic decision was “keep quiet and hope no one notices.”

The uproar around the [incoming partnership class at Paul Weiss](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/paul-weiss-press-release-captures-everything-broken-about-biglaw-in-one-image/) highlighted this “market of ideas” failure in the media business — this reliance on transparency as a springboard to criticism that incentivizes others to recede into opacity. When Paul Weiss announced an almost entirely white male incoming class with a lone white woman to round out the class, the image the firm released — more so even than the promotions themselves — captured the diversity problem in Biglaw because someone along the way never thought an image like that could be anything but ordinary.

But precisely because this was Paul Weiss, the firm addressed the matter swiftly and set aside an opportunity to discuss what happened with the whole firm and have already taken steps to [improve diversity through the lateral market](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/01/paul-weiss-launches-supreme-court-practice-as-press-spotlight-returns-to-partnership-diversity/).

While improving diversity in the legal profession is a task every firm needs to commit to with far more vigor, the attention heaped upon Paul Weiss always seemed a bit disproportionate. While the image captured the broad struggle across Biglaw, there are certainly firms doing far less to address improve diversity both firmwide and in particular in senior leadership positions. To some extent, Paul Weiss bore the brunt of an industry crisis because it happened to offer transparency. There’s not an easy way to see that, for example, Cravath has no black partners. Therefore Paul Weiss’s name gets associated with diversity struggles that it addresses better than many of its peer firms while those firms avoid the spotlight.

This is an industry-wide problem and one that all firms need to redouble their efforts upon. Whenever we report on diversity in firms — both the successes and the failures — those of us covering the issue need to underscore for the readers that we’re only reporting on a slice of a wider crisis and that no success can be celebrated or failure lamented without grasping how it fits into the overarching diversity landscape.

Trees still make a sound when they fall no matter how cagey your press strategy.

# The Reason Why Milbank Raised Associate Salaries
## Associates shouldn't have to wait 10 years for a raise.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onJune 4, 2018 at 2:31 PMJune 5, 2018 at 9:46 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/the-reason-why-milbank-raised-associate-salaries/&text=The%20Reason%20Why%20Milbank%20Raised%20Associate%20Salaries)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/the-reason-why-milbank-raised-associate-salaries/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/the-reason-why-milbank-raised-associate-salaries/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Two years have now gone by, and there is cost-of-living increases and inflation. We want to signal to the market that we do want the best, and we’re willing to pay for the best, and we think after two years, an additional increase is appropriate.

— Milbank chairman Scott Edelman, [in an interview with Law.com](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2018/06/04/milbank-boosts-associate-salaries-with-190k-starting-pay/) explaining why the firm [raised associate salaries across the board.](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/new-york-to-190k-no-cravath-didnt-make-the-first-move/) Associates will receive raises between $10,000 and $15,000, depending on seniority. Two years ago, [Cravath started a salary war](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/breaking-ny-to-180k-cravath-raises-associate-base-salaries/) when the firm moved the Biglaw market to $180,000 for first-year associates after a nearly 10-year period of stagnation.

# Biglaw Firm Beats Cravath Scale With Special Bonuses
## Beating the market once again.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onDecember 8, 2016 at 4:58 PMDecember 9, 2016 at 11:20 AM
1
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/biglaw-firm-beats-cravath-scale-with-special-bonuses/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Beats%20Cravath%20Scale%20With%20Special%20Bonuses)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/biglaw-firm-beats-cravath-scale-with-special-bonuses/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/biglaw-firm-beats-cravath-scale-with-special-bonuses/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Cravath may have [set the standard](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/11/associate-bonus-watch-cravath-announces-its-2016-associate-bonuses/) but Cahill, Gordon & Reindel is coming over the top. In addition to the standard, end of the year bonuses — which mirror the standard set by CSM — associates in good standing are getting special bonuses from $10,000 to $40,000 depending on class year as follows:



The bonuses will be paid in January — the 6th for the special bonus, and the end of January for the end of year bonus. Tipsters report they are “pretty excited” about the news, and with paydays this big, who can blame them?

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Cahill has a history of beating the market: in the past they’ve offered special bonuses in the [summer](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/07/associate-bonus-watch-biglaw-summer-bonuses/?rf=1) and at the [end of the year](https://abovethelaw.com/2014/12/associate-bonus-watch-cahill-gordon-beats-the-market-once-again/) so the associates could share in the bounty. But [last year](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/01/associate-bonus-watch-a-former-bonus-leader-takes-a-tumble/) Cahill met the going market rate, but did no more. While at plenty of firms meeting the market standard would be cause for cheer, it was met with concern at Cahill. It’s good to see times are good again at 80 Pine Street and the recent associate raises didn’t trade off with bonuses.

So how’s all this extra money treating you Cahill people? Feel free to sound off [by email](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Bonus), by text message (646-820-8477), or by tweet ([@ATLblog](https://twitter.com/atlblog)). A fun or insightful response — we’ll keep you anonymous — could find its way into an update to this story.

Please help us help you when it comes to bonus news at other firms. As soon as your firm’s bonus memo comes out, please [email it to us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Bonus) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Bonus”) or text us (646-820-8477). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts, please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

# Major Biglaw Firm Matches The 2022 Baker/Cravath Bonus Scale
## It's bonus time at this leading law firm!
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onNovember 30, 2022 at 2:25 PMNovember 30, 2022 at 4:10 PM
18
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/11/mcdermott-will-bonus-2022/&text=Major%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Matches%20The%202022%20Baker/Cravath%20Bonus%20Scale)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/11/mcdermott-will-bonus-2022/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/11/mcdermott-will-bonus-2022/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Cravath finally offered its [seal of approval](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/11/cravath-bonuses-22/) on the [Baker McKenzie bonus scale](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/11/biglaw-bonus-season-begins/) last night, with some notable dissimilarities — the compensation leader included first-years while excluding eighth-years from its own scale. And so, Cravath has now officially kicked off Biglaw’s bonus season, while curiously offering other firms the option to leave their eldest associates out of the annual cash grab. (But do note, of course, that not being included in the lockstep bonus chart leaves room for sometimes great, sometimes not-so great individualized bonuses.) Now, another elite law firm has jumped to match the market rate as quickly as possible.

Which firm is the first to “match” Cravath’s Biglaw bonus scale?

McDermott Will & Emery — a firm that brought in $1,665,221,000 gross revenue in 2021 — is the first firm to hop on the Cravath bonus bandwagon. This is a blended Baker/Cravath bonus, in that the firm is handing out money to both first- and eighth-years at the firm. Bonuses at the firm will be paid to all associates in good standing on December 29, 2022. There’s just one teeny caveat: to be eligible for a bonus, an associate must have joined the firm prior to August 1, 2022.

Here’s the bonus scale, in case you’ve forgotten what it looks like:

- Class of 2022: $15,000 (pro-rated)
- Class of 2021: $20,000
- Class of 2020: $30,000
- Class of 2019: $57,500
- Class of 2018: $75,000
- Class of 2017: $90,000
- Class of 2016: $105,000
- Class of 2015+: $115,000
It’s worth noting that McDermott Will is paying significantly above these amounts for those who went “above and beyond.” Here’s an excerpt from the firm’s memo (available in full on the next page):

We are always committed to paying at—and above—the Cravath scale for those who meet our reasonable threshold. As you know, we do not use a lockstep model and we choose to use an individual merit-based system endorsed by our Associates’ Committee and Firm leadership. This approach provides for substantial incremental bonuses for those who go above and beyond in terms of hours expectations and performance. In fact, about 65% of our Associates will earn above the Cravath scale.

Congratulations to all MWE associates on the generous bonuses!

(Does this mean that associates’ hopes for another firm to step in and raise the bonus scale higher will be dashed? That’s uncertain, but we’ll be watching.)

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of important bonus updates, so when your firm announces or matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish. Thanks for your help!

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

# Guilty Of Multitasking
## Ah, the sweet, sweet sound that is the siren's song we all call multitasking.
By [Meyling "Mey" Ly Ortiz](https://abovethelaw.com/author/mortiz/)  
onJune 29, 2023 at 3:48 PMJune 29, 2023 at 1:00 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/guilty-of-multitasking/&text=Guilty%20Of%20Multitasking)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/guilty-of-multitasking/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/guilty-of-multitasking/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Photo via Getty)

In our post-pandemic, virtual, or hybrid work environment, it is super-tempting to multitask during a meeting or conference call with a lot of attendees, especially if you’re not critical to the event. Of course, if you’re not critical, I want to ask you why you’re there in the first place … but I also understand that some meetings are unavoidable, and the likely answer is that you were invited.

I am the first to admit that multitasking is a siren’s call that is extremely difficult for me to resist. There’s some kind of endorphin kick I get from being able to maximize my time despite all the studies out there that say multitasking is not actually productive. (But why does it feel so good?!?)

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Now, I am not so bold as to respond to substantive emails — that’s a rookie move where you are likely to make typos and mistakes, not a good look for a legal professional. But I am the first to admit that I might skim and prioritize my inbox, organize my OneNote, or skim my LinkedIn if I have determined that whatever meeting I’m in doesn’t pertain to me. I have also been known to water my plants, transfer the laundry from washer to dryer, or get on the treadmill to get a few more steps in — all on mute, of course.

If you’re like me and can’t help it, here are a few tips that I’ve picked up.

Exercise Good Judgment And Choose Wisely

Before multitasking, be aware of your audience and the topic of the meeting and be sure that you’re really not critical. Professional reputation and branding is important so you wouldn’t want to risk appearing absent around your client or your leadership when you’re supposed to be engaged and responsive.

###Sponsored

From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)

[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Gotta Be Listening … Some

You do need to stay engaged enough to respond if you get called on. This is why I wouldn’t recommend that your second task is something that requires focus. You do not want to risk zoning out and missing the question posed to you during the call while you were in deep analysis of a complex legal issue for another client.

Disclosure Can Be Your Friend

In moments of need, such as having a sick baby at home or while in transit during kid pickup or just at the airport, where I have to join a call because of its urgency or importance, I like to disclose my unique situation from the beginning. Sometimes clients can’t find any time on my calendar so I will necessarily offer up “after hours,” but fully disclosing that I’ll have to start dinner or simultaneously manage the kids (aka give them a screen) until my spouse (who has a long commute) gets home. I have never asked for direct feedback, but my hope is that my clients or leadership appreciate me doing my best to show up for their needs and appreciate the honesty.

# These Firms Are Feasting On Stroock's Partners
## Partner? Partner.
By [Chris Williams](https://abovethelaw.com/author/cwilliams/)  
onNovember 13, 2023 at 12:48 PMNovember 13, 2023 at 11:55 AM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/these-firms-are-feasting-on-stroocks-partners/&text=These%20Firms%20Are%20Feasting%20On%20Stroock’s%20Partners)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/these-firms-are-feasting-on-stroocks-partners/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/these-firms-are-feasting-on-stroocks-partners/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

No need to worry about merging anymore!

After 147 years of service, Stroock & Stroock & Lavan will soon join the great law firm in the sky. And though the firm may die, the partners live on. And the great Macklemore once said, one firms’s partner run is another firm’s come-up. With the way that these firms have been gobbling up Stroock’s talent, it looks like Thanksgiving came early. From [Reuters](https://www.reuters.com/legal/legalindustry/demise-147-year-old-stroock-is-boon-law-firm-rivals-2023-11-13/):

Crowell & Moring, Hogan Lovells, Steptoe & Johnson, Squire Patton Boggs and Thompson Coburn are among the law firms that have so far hired partners and other lawyers from Stroock, helping them quickly expand in New York and elsewhere.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Much of the Stroock dissolution coverage is partner focused, but we want to know how the rest of the firm is faring. Are you an associate at Stroock who’s found a home at another Biglaw firm? Are you using this as [an opportunity to change tracks for a boutique](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/cohen-ziffers-managing-partner-on-why-choosing-a-boutique-firm-may-be-the-best-career-move-you-make/)? Our vast network of tipsters is part of what makes Above the Law thrive. You can [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com) or text us ([646-820-8477](tel:646-820-8477)). Thank you for your assistance.

[Demise Of 147-Year-Old Stroock Is Boon For Law Firm Rivals](https://www.reuters.com/legal/legalindustry/demise-147-year-old-stroock-is-boon-law-firm-rivals-2023-11-13/) [Reuters]

Chris Williams became a social media manager and assistant editor for Above the Law in June 2021. Prior to joining the staff, he moonlighted as a minor Memelord™ in the Facebook group [Law School Memes for Edgy T14s](https://www.facebook.com/photo/?fbid=10222912314148913&set=p.10222912314148913&opaqueCursor=AboVBPzRKh4loie1LupyI7ltSvsaUWxURlMk_338xXb_BPhzMNPHbWfVDUsOyUH1mfvHQ4Bsipef989J-V0OyqhMZzHPafTw49vttxDh_no8xymRSSUssmh47qTzHAc13R0wzk8nPhgSylnSAYcBNbHjYDqZDqy5r0f7PwzCZw9T-0cakKMIin3XI0O8R5H5OJGAu4kJjGPAoZpgL6woU9lwoHiAjxAwAlpmdlyt6vHLJ1TVn2srkC3G4qBW5ANthJ_YNT3BUPCu2vu1ZIxiqYwXGLfMIxQR4cllUaB0Cja74ln1FHs3n-xyHe6MDtxln0-F4QJchox9nCaivB_xmSxw3FduERhPebhWj1MKJ20jeucGZ64jY6DdUn2d87dVgNlFE5qHvNEtfMpoEKx1096oFfqbZ9s71YVsbXxLIsRiiW54eLp4R7z3WHAKu8v8xeLIZt86UVU1iOaSlJ0n5tT3_VonQT6n2F0sIUSLY272cI-yjWxaUIr0Qj-1NQDFFcn9dkq8pYV2-o0M3LK2Qhr9LKt-Bk4MTGUZCkb4Kw6mgDmRCux3nhJqd2hdLd8LgTA).  He endured Missouri long enough to graduate from Washington University in St. Louis School of Law. He is a former boatbuilder who cannot swim, [a published author on critical race theory, philosophy, and humor](https://www.academia.edu/33296970/Lets_Be_Frank_Parrhesia_and_the_Black_Comedic_Tradition), and has a love for cycling that occasionally annoys his peers. You can reach him by email at [cwilliams@abovethelaw.com](mailto:cwilliams@abovethelaw.com) and by tweet at [@WritesForRent](https://twitter.com/WritesForRent).

# Biglaw Firm Changes Tack After Diversity Lawsuit
## The Supreme Court has forced changes to Biglaw's diversity programs.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onOctober 6, 2023 at 2:45 PMOctober 6, 2023 at 2:41 PM
11
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/perkins-coie-diversity-fellowship/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Changes%20Tack%20After%20Diversity%20Lawsuit)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/perkins-coie-diversity-fellowship/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/perkins-coie-diversity-fellowship/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Perkins Coie, one of the Biglaw firms under fire for its diversity fellowship, has decided to rewrite its program in light of the Supreme Court’s recent decision dismantling affirmative action in colleges. In August, Perkins and Morrison & Foerster were [sued over their fellowships](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/two-biglaw-firms-sued-over-diversity-initiatives/). The plaintiff is The American Alliance for Equal Rights, founded by Edward Blum — the same person behind Students for Fair Admissions, the plaintiff in the affirmative action Supreme Court case.

According to a[ statement ](https://www.perkinscoie.com/en/about-us/firm/diversity/diversity-recruitment.html)on the firm’s website, the new fellowship will be open to all, as opposed to its previous program which was for applicants from “historically underrepresented” groups, but is designed to still promote diversity.

The new Diversity and Inclusion Fellowship Program expands the applicant pool to all and clarifies the factors that the firm will consider in selecting fellows. The revised criteria will ensure that the firm continues to hire accomplished lawyers with a diversity of backgrounds and experiences. These changes arose from an update to Perkins Coie’s D&I policies that began shortly after the U.S. Supreme Court decision in the Students for Fair Admissions Inc. v. President & Fellows of Harvard College case earlier this year.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Genhi Givings Bailey, Perkins Coie’s chief diversity and inclusion officer, commented on the change, saying, “Our new Diversity and Inclusion Fellowship Program continues Perkins Coie’s long-standing and deep-rooted commitment to advancing diversity, equity, and inclusion within our firm and across the legal profession. We are proud of our firm’s progress and even as the legal landscape evolves, our commitment to strengthening diversity and creating a more inclusive workplace remains steadfast.”

The well-crafted statement on diversity is only a part of the firm’s commitment to diversity. Attorneys also have a 50-billable-hour credit they can use for DEI-related activities — a program unlikely to be impacted by the new legal landscape.

Previously, Senator [Tom Cotton threatened Biglaw firms](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/tom-cotton-threatens-top-biglaw-firms-over-their-diversity-inclusion-initiatives/) over their DEI initiatives. However, the industry[ hasn’t done much](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/biglaw-firms-dont-seem-to-care-about-tom-cottons-anti-diversity-legal-threats/) more than shrug in response to that threat.

Earlier: [Biglaw Caves: Morrison Foerster Changes Diversity Fellowship Criteria Following Lawsuit](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/biglaw-caves-morrison-foerster-changes-diversity-fellowship-criteria-following-lawsuit/)
[Two Biglaw Firms Sued Over Diversity Initiatives](http://Two%20Biglaw%20Firms%20Sued%20Over%20Diversity%20Initiatives)

# Why The Anti-Résumé Provokes Such Strong Reactions
## Who you are affects how you react to what I write.
By [Mark Herrmann](https://abovethelaw.com/author/mark-herrmann/)  
onMay 2, 2022 at 2:18 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/05/why-the-anti-resume-provokes-such-strong-reactions/&text=Why%20The%20Anti-Résumé%20Provokes%20Such%20Strong%20Reactions)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/05/why-the-anti-resume-provokes-such-strong-reactions/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/05/why-the-anti-resume-provokes-such-strong-reactions/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(via Getty Images)

Several weeks ago, I suggested that, when people draft their résumés, they should be required simultaneously to draft [their anti-résumés](https://www.blogger.com/blog/post/edit/4454944101251496/3135964485077648547), highlighting all the failures in their lives — awards they didn’t win, clerkships they didn’t obtain, firms that didn’t hire them, trials they lost, and the rest.

The reaction to this column was fierce, with some readers saying the idea of writing an anti-résumé was a terrible one, sure to depress people and likely to cause suicides. How could I have written such dangerous words?

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
On the other hand, many people reacted to the column differently: “That was the funniest thing I’ve read in a long time! Thanks for writing it!”

Why the divide?

The audience at Above the Law, of course, contains many categories of people.  Some of those people are high-achieving folks who went to the best law schools, served on law reviews, landed fancy clerkships, and are now partners at the finest firms in the country.

The vast majority of readers, of course, don’t fall into that category.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)

From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)

Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Who you are affects how you react to what I write.

I wrote the anti-résumé column as a joke. As an in-house lawyer, I’m bombarded by résumés of people telling me how great they are: I should hire them for in-house jobs; I should retain them for big litigation; and so on. Sitting in my place, you too might think that folks should be required to write an anti-résumé: The whole world is insisting that it’s great, and it’s not really that great. Wouldn’t it be funny if people had to tell the truth?

On the other hand, if you’re consumed by the idea of professional “success” — good grades, fancy clerkship, fancy job — and you’ve never attained that traditional success, then you might not view the idea of an anti-résumé as a cute joke. Rather, you might be bemoaning your lack of “success” in life and dismayed by the thought that you should be required to wallow in your self-evident “failures.” If you had to draft an anti-résumé, that could drive you over the edge — to drink, to drugs, to suicide. How could I have proposed such a thing?

I surely hope that the piece of my readership that I didn’t hear from falls into a different category — a well-adjusted middle. I assume that my average reader is average — went to an average school, performed about average, and went on to an average career. But if that hypothetical reader is emotionally secure and well-adjusted, then that reader should be satisfied with his or her life: Success is not, after all, a function of grades or clerkships or partnerships.

Success is, more or less, leaving the world a better place for your having lived in it.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)

From Pilot and Above The Law

[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
With luck, you get to live your threescore years and ten. During that time, did you improve the lives of your friends and family? Of your community or the world at large? Did you appreciate the good times as you lived them? Did you help those in need?

I think — I hope — that emotionally well-adjusted readers smiled at my joke about the anti-résumé.

But the reactions to the column made me more sensitive to the spectrum of readers who visit Above the Law.

Mark Herrmann spent 17 years as a partner at a leading international law firm and is now deputy general counsel at a large international company. He is the author of [The Curmudgeon’s Guide to Practicing Law](https://www.amazon.com/Curmudgeons-Guide-Practicing-Law/dp/1641054336/ref=pd_lpo_14_t_0/144-3788773-6854967?_encoding=UTF8&pd_rd_i=1641054336&pd_rd_r=61f38502-781d-47fb-a260-1970deea4a4d&pd_rd_w=AWqCy&pd_rd_wg=kFTh8&pf_rd_p=7b36d496-f366-4631-94d3-61b87b52511b&pf_rd_r=YK5GGKBGTD85BA2P42XB&psc=1&refRID=YK5GGKBGTD85BA2P42XB) and [Drug and Device Product Liability Litigation Strateg](http://www.amazon.com/Device-Product-Liability-Litigation-Strategy/dp/0198803532/ref=sr_1_fkmr0_1?keywords=%22drug+and+device+product+liability+litigation+strategy%22+second&qid=1578409788&s=books&sr=1-1-fkmr0)[y](http://www.amazon.com/Device-Product-Liability-Litigation-Strategy/dp/0198803532/ref=sr_1_fkmr0_1?keywords=%22drug+and+device+product+liability+litigation+strategy%22+second&qid=1578409788&s=books&sr=1-1-fkmr0) (affiliate links). You can reach him by email at [inhouse@abovethelaw.com](mailto:inhouse@abovethelaw.com).

# Perhaps Comedians Could Provide Viral Moments For Politicians In Debates?
## Most moments that go viral these days are nasty ones. We don't need our national discourse to become nastier than it already is.
By [Mark Herrmann](https://abovethelaw.com/author/mark-herrmann/)  
onSeptember 11, 2023 at 10:49 AM
8
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/perhaps-comedians-could-provide-viral-moments-for-politicians-in-debates/&text=Perhaps%20Comedians%20Could%20Provide%20Viral%20Moments%20For%20Politicians%20In%20Debates?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/perhaps-comedians-could-provide-viral-moments-for-politicians-in-debates/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/perhaps-comedians-could-provide-viral-moments-for-politicians-in-debates/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Political debates are not about policy. No one cares about policy.

Political debates are a little bit about politicians’ height and weight and hair. People love to talk about that.

Political debates are a great deal about whether politicians seem like the kind of people you’d like to have a beer with. Political scientists say that matters.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
But, more than anything else, in today’s environment, political debates are about politicians’ ability to create viral moments. If a politician can say something — anything — that can be caught in a 30-second sound bite and circulated around the internet, that’s victory.

Unfortunately, most moments that go viral these days are nasty ones. One politician says something vindictive about another, pulling the second person up short; the internet loves it. That might be good for one of the politicians, but it’s bad for America. We don’t need our national discourse to become nastier than it already is.

Here’s a thought: Why don’t politicians hire comedians to work on their staffs?

Jokes go viral all the time. If a politician told a good joke, the politician would be almost certain to go viral.

### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Surely a good comedian could come up with three or four short, pithy, jocular, and meaningful one- or two-liners for politicians to hold in their back pockets during a debate. If the opportunity arose, a politician could spring one, creating a viral moment that showed them to be clever, friendly, funny, and just the sort of person you’d like to have a beer with.

I don’t mean nasty humor; that defeats half the purpose of this. I mean clever, funny, nice, or perhaps self-deprecating humor. I’m thinking of 73-year-old Ronald Reagan, accused of being too old to run for a second term, telling Walter Mondale that Reagan wouldn’t hold Mondale’s  “[youth and inexperience](https://www.reaganfoundation.org/ronald-reagan/reagan-quotes-speeches/debate-between-the-president-and-former-vice-president-walter-f-mondale-in-kansas-city-missouri/)” against him in the 1984 campaign.

Or, perhaps not as memorably, [Al Gore telling Jack Kemp](https://www.britannica.com/list/11-memorable-quotes-from-us-presidential-debates) during the 1996 vice-presidential debate that: “If you won’t use any football stories, I won’t tell any of my warm and humorous stories about chlorofluorocarbon abatement.”

Those debates were before the age of social media, so you can’t be sure that the one-liners would have gone viral. But I suspect they would have; they’re perfect for the medium.

Funny one-liners would win attention for politicians, show the politicians to be affable and witty, and surely raise their standing in the polls.

Politicians can’t do much about their height or appearance, but they could do an awful lot to make the public think that they were personable. Aren’t they missing a trick not putting a comedian on the staff?

Mark Herrmann spent 17 years as a partner at a leading international law firm and is now deputy general counsel at a large international company. He is the author of [The Curmudgeon’s Guide to Practicing Law](https://www.amazon.com/Curmudgeons-Guide-Practicing-Law/dp/1641054336/ref=pd_lpo_14_t_0/144-3788773-6854967?_encoding=UTF8&pd_rd_i=1641054336&pd_rd_r=61f38502-781d-47fb-a260-1970deea4a4d&pd_rd_w=AWqCy&pd_rd_wg=kFTh8&pf_rd_p=7b36d496-f366-4631-94d3-61b87b52511b&pf_rd_r=YK5GGKBGTD85BA2P42XB&psc=1&refRID=YK5GGKBGTD85BA2P42XB) and [Drug and Device Product Liability Litigation Strateg](http://www.amazon.com/Device-Product-Liability-Litigation-Strategy/dp/0198803532/ref=sr_1_fkmr0_1?keywords=%22drug+and+device+product+liability+litigation+strategy%22+second&qid=1578409788&s=books&sr=1-1-fkmr0)[y](http://www.amazon.com/Device-Product-Liability-Litigation-Strategy/dp/0198803532/ref=sr_1_fkmr0_1?keywords=%22drug+and+device+product+liability+litigation+strategy%22+second&qid=1578409788&s=books&sr=1-1-fkmr0) (affiliate links). # Summer Associate Hopes Firm Meeting Doesn't Interfere With Gym Time
## Not every question is a good question.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onMay 31, 2019 at 11:44 AMMay 31, 2019 at 3:14 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/05/summer-associate-hopes-firm-meeting-doesnt-interfere-with-gym-time/&text=Summer%20Associate%20Hopes%20Firm%20Meeting%20Doesn’t%20Interfere%20With%20Gym%20Time)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/05/summer-associate-hopes-firm-meeting-doesnt-interfere-with-gym-time/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/05/summer-associate-hopes-firm-meeting-doesnt-interfere-with-gym-time/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Once more, Biglaw enters the summer season and that means we’re due for Summer Associates making a string of professional errors befitting a rookie attorney. Usually we have to wait until [somebody gets drunk](https://abovethelaw.com/2010/08/a-collection-of-funny-summer-associate-stories-from-a-bygone-age/), a development that’s becoming [increasingly rare in Biglaw programs](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/biglaw-summer-programs-phasing-out-boozefests-to-create-all-new-worse-sexual-harassment-opportunities/). This time we have a summer who’s on a strong enough health kick that he really wants to skip the morning meeting:

Is attendance at the 7:30am breakfast mandatory? I already wake up at 5am to make it to the gym before work. I’m not sure I can handle a 3am wakeup time.

Or you could skip the gym for one day instead of blowing off a professional meeting. It’s hard to imagine this breakfast meeting is a daily event throughout the summer. If it is, start working out in the evenings. At least consider these before asking a firm attorney to skip out.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Also… four and a half hours of gym time? Good for you!

This “Summer As-SWOLE-ciate” provides a teachable moment for all Summers: if you’re invited to something as a Summer… you should treat it as mandatory. Your role at this stage in your career is to throw yourself into every professional opportunity. Demonstrate an eagerness to take on everything, especially an entirely low-impact morning practice group meeting.

We have no idea how this email exchange ended up, but we assume the query was shot down prompting the follow-up, “do you even lift, bro?”

# Kirkland Uses Its Immense Wealth In Pursuit Of Associates
## It's the hottest associate lateral market in history, and Kirkland is making moves.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onApril 28, 2021 at 3:15 PMApril 29, 2021 at 1:43 PM
6
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/kirkland-uses-its-immense-wealth-in-pursuit-of-associates/&text=Kirkland%20Uses%20Its%20Immense%20Wealth%20In%20Pursuit%20Of%20Associates)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/kirkland-uses-its-immense-wealth-in-pursuit-of-associates/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/kirkland-uses-its-immense-wealth-in-pursuit-of-associates/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
We told you the associate [lateral market is hot like fire](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/the-biglaw-lateral-market-is-fire-right-now/) rn. And boy, we weren’t kidding. We all know — and have covered ad nauseam — that [special bonuses](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/special-bonus-tracker-2021/) are sweeping through the elite of Biglaw, which are likely part of a calculated move to keep associates happy enough to stay put at their current firms. And [other perks](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/dont-throw-clients-under-the-bus-unless-theyre-protesters/) are being thrown into the mix — like[ $1,000 worth of takeout](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/kirkland-sweetens-associate-perks-with-free-food/?rf=1) or [$1,500 in exercise equipment](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/grading-all-the-davis-polk-gift-bonuses/).

But Biglaw giants looking to entice associates away from their firms are also here to play. And Kirkland & Ellis, the firm consistently taking in the most money in gross revenue, has plenty of money to throw at new hires. As [reported by Law.com](https://www.law.com/2021/04/28/kirkland-emerges-as-top-competitor-in-associate-talent-battle/), they aren’t shy about it either:

For instance, Kirkland offered a third-year associate at another firm a $150,000 signing bonus; offered another candidate $50,000, plus a possible top year-end bonus and an earlier path to partnership; and offered a retention bonus to a current associate to match a signing bonus from another firm, according to a source familiar with the bonuses.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
In fact, Chicago-based recruiter Kay Hoppe characterizes this as “the most aggressive associate market in history,” so it’s no wonder firms are doing everything in their power to woo the best associates:

“I handle elite partner [moves]. Everybody wants them, But more than them, they need associates,” Hoppe said. “There’s more need than there is talent. And I wouldn’t fault Kirkland or anybody else for doing what they are doing for bringing in top associates.”

“The whole thing is upside down right now,” she said about the demand for associates compared with partners. “I have no problem with a firm offering a great associate the world, because they’re needed. And the best of the best provide something that is invaluable to the clients, to the partners and to their peers.”

It’s good to see firms realizing they need to up their game to keep their associates or to attract new ones. And for all the associates out there, go find your bliss (or at least the Biglaw firm that can give you the nearest simulacrum of happy).
